steps.title: Apply first aid to any wounds
steps.content: Apply first aid to any wounds around the injury. Sanitize your hands and check for any cuts, scrapes, punctures, or other wounds. Then, clean the wound and bandage it. [1] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Make sure that the wound is completely clean and covered up before you apply any type of splint. [2] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Apply firm pressure to any wounds to help stop the bleeding. [3] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Call emergency services right away if the injured person continues to bleed profusely, even if you aren’t close to a hospital. The sooner medical help arrives, the better. [4] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Look around for something rigid, like a stick or board.
steps.content: Look around for something rigid, like a stick or board. Search for something that’s both sturdy and big enough to support the injured body part, like a rolled-up section of a newspaper. Items like rolled-up clothes and blankets can work if you’re in a pinch. [5] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Walking sticks and trekking poles are both great options. [6] X Research source For smaller injuries, like a finger fracture, you can use the neighboring finger as a “sturdy object.” [7] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source If the elbow or shoulder is injured, tuck the person’s arm close to their body and wrap the whole torso, immobilizing the limb against the body. For these injuries, it’s better to make a soft splint like a sling rather than making a rigid splint. This treatment also works well for wrist or forearm injuries. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Splint the injured body part without adjusting it.
steps.content: Splint the injured body part without adjusting it. It can be concerning to find a bent or misaligned limb, but never try to straighten or realign the injury on your own. Any type of adjustment could risk making the injury even worse. Instead, treat and splint the injury in the exact position you find it in. [9] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Plan to splint around the neighboring joints.
steps.content: Plan to splint around the neighboring joints. The goal of a makeshift splint is to keep the injury stable and immobile. Let’s say that someone injured their lower leg on a hike—to best support the injury, you’d splint the ankle and knee as well as the leg. [10] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Here are a few best practices for other types of injuries: Ankle: Splint from foot to mid-calf Thumb: Splint from mid-palm to mid-forearm Fingers: Splint from the injured fingers to the wrist Wrist: Splint from the hand to the elbow [11] X Research source

steps.title: Pad the area between the injured limb and the splint.
steps.content: Pad the area between the injured limb and the splint. Gently surround the injury with some sort of soft material, like a shirt or jacket—this will act as a cushion between the injury and the splint itself. Be sure to place plenty of padding around any bony and swollen parts of the injury, especially. [12] X Research source Make sure that the padding is snug around the injury without cutting off circulation.

steps.title: Apply the splint to one side of the injury.
steps.content: Apply the splint to one side of the injury. Take the rigid item that you grabbed earlier and gently place it along the injured body part. Whenever possible, line the splint along the uninjured side of the limb. [13] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source For example, you could brace a leg injury by placing a long, rigid walking stick beneath the person’s leg (under the knee). You could brace an injured forearm by placing the rigid item beneath the arm (in line with the palm). [14] X Research source

steps.title: Tie the splint to keep it in place.
steps.content: Tie the splint to keep it in place. Anything thin and flexible can work for this, like a belt, necktie, or section of tape. Arrange these along the top and bottom of the splint (near the joints), so you aren’t putting any pressure on the injury itself. [15] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Tie your splint securely, but make sure that it isn’t too tight. A really tight splint could prevent circulation.

steps.title: Make a hand splint
steps.content: Make a hand splint with a clean cloth. Treating hand injuries requires a different splinting process. Set a soft object (like a rolled-up sock) or a cloth ball under the injured person’s hand so their fingers are resting on top of the soft item. Then, stick strips of clean cloth in between the injured fingers to act as padding. Wrap a clean piece of cloth all the way around the injured hand, followed by a second layer of cloth to help hold everything in place. [16] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source You can use adhesive tape instead of cloth for the second layer of your splint. Wrap 4 strips of cloth or tape between the gaps of the fingers before you wrap the second layer of cloth around the injury. This helps keep them separated. Make sure the person’s fingertips are completely exposed and uncovered by the splint. This way, you can test their circulation easily.

steps.title: Check the injury frequently to make sure it isn’t getting worse.
steps.content: Check the injury frequently to make sure it isn’t getting worse. Once your splint is in place, inspect the injury once every couple of minutes to see if it looks more swollen or pale than it did before. If so, loosen the bindings around the makeshift splint a little bit. Check the patient’s pulse to make sure they have enough circulation around their injury. If their pulse feels faint, loosen the splint ties a little bit. Check in with the injured individual, too. Ask them if their injury feels numb at all—if it does, loosen up the ties. [17] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Watch for any warning signs of shock, like short, quick breathing. If the person’s injuries allow it, lay them down with their legs elevated and their head a little lower than their chest. [18] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Take the injured individual to a hospital ASAP.
steps.content: Take the injured individual to a hospital ASAP. Splints are an invaluable resource when you’re stuck in the middle of nowhere, but they aren’t a replacement for a professional medical diagnosis and treatment. Take the injured individual to a hospital as soon as possible to prevent any complications. [19] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Treat any immediate injuries.
steps.content: Treat any immediate injuries. Wash your hands and clean out any scrapes, cuts, punctures, or other wounds surrounding the injured body part. Bandage and dress these wounds completely before you start applying the splint. [20] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source If you’re creating a splint for an open fracture (where the bone is sticking out of the skin), gently place a saline-moistened piece of sterile gauze on top of the injury.

steps.title: Choose the best splint for the injury.
steps.content: Choose the best splint for the injury. Different types of splints yield better results, depending on which body part is hurt. Here are a few different types of splints you might consider: Colle’s/Volar: Best for upper forearm injuries Long arm or gutter: Best for wrist, forearm, and metacarpal proximal phalanx injuries Sugar tong: Best for elbow and upper arm injuries (needs to be used with a sling) Thumb spica: Best for thumb or scaphoid injuries Long leg: Best for lower femur or upper tibia/fibula injuries Posterior (short) leg: Best for lower tibia/fibula, foot, or ankle injuries Stirrup: Best for ankle injuries (even if the injury only affects the soft tissue) [21] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source

steps.title: Protect the patient’s clothing before applying the splint.
steps.content: Protect the patient’s clothing before applying the splint. If time permits, drape a sheet or gown on top of the patient before you do anything else. This helps protect their skin and clothing from the water and plaster you’ll use to make the splint.

steps.title: Apply a stockinette to protect the patient’s skin.
steps.content: Apply a stockinette to protect the patient’s skin. Grab a section of stockinette that’s at least 10 cm (3.9 in) longer than the splint and slide it on top of the injured body part (wherever the splint will go). Once the splint is complete, you’ll fold the extra stockinette fabric over the edges to create a smooth finish. A stockinette is a thin layer of fabric that creates a barrier between the patient’s skin and the splinting.

steps.title: Measure and cut your splinting material.
steps.content: Measure and cut your splinting material. Hold the splinting material next to the injured body part and mark off a section that’s long enough to cover the surrounding joints. Then, measure around the injury—the splint needs to be wide enough to cover about half of the circumference of the injured body part. Cut the splinting material down to size once you’ve collected your measurements. [22] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source Finger splints are typically 2 in (5.1 cm) wide, arm splints are usually 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm) wide, and leg splints are traditionally 5 to 6 in (13 to 15 cm) wide. Plaster splinting material usually comes in prefabricated splint rolls, with each roll having about 10-20 plaster sheets in it. Plaster of Paris is another popular type of splinting plaster—it usually comes in rolls or strips. Make your measurement slightly longer if you’re working with Plaster of Paris strips or rolls, since this material often shrinks a little when the splint sets. [23] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source

steps.title: Choose a splint thickness that best suits the patient’s injury.
steps.content: Choose a splint thickness that best suits the patient’s injury. About 8-10 layers of plaster will get the job done if you’re splinting an arm, wrist, or shoulder injury, while leg and ankle splints typically need 12-14 layers. [24] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source

steps.title: Wrap Webril padding around the limb on top of the stockinette.
steps.content: Wrap Webril padding around the limb on top of the stockinette. Grab a roll of Webril splint padding and carefully loop it around the stockinette. Divide the total number of plaster layers you’ll be using by 2—this is how many wrap-arounds of padding you’ll need for the splint. [25] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source If you plan on splinting an arm with 10 layers of plaster, only use 5 layers of padding. If you plan on splinting a leg injury with 13 layers of plaster, just use 6-7 layers of padding.

steps.title: Double-check the injury to make sure it’s positioned correctly.
steps.content: Double-check the injury to make sure it’s positioned correctly. Make sure that the body part is in a completely immobile position where it can heal properly. [26] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source Radial/Ulnar gutter: Make sure that the forearm is vertically upright. Thumb spica: Place the wrist in a completely neutral position with the thumb pointed out. Volar/Colles: Arrange the wrist in a neutral position with all 5 fingers slightly bent. Long arm or sugar tong: Lay the patient face-down and bend their arm around the side of the bed/stretcher at a right angle. Posterior (short) leg or stirrup: Sit the patient upright and have them bend their knee at a right angle. Make sure that the connected foot also creates a right angle with their leg.

steps.title: Soak your splint material in water and squeeze it out.
steps.content: Soak your splint material in water and squeeze it out. Dip the plaster in a basin of clean, room temperature water—or, water that's around 24 °C (75 °F). Then, carefully squeeze out any leftover water from the soaked plaster so it’s not dripping wet. [27] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source It also helps to smooth out the damp plaster on a flat surface to get rid of any wrinkles or grooves. [28] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source It should have a really sloppy texture at this point. Never use hot water to apply a splint. Wetting the plaster generates heat—when combined with hot water (especially water that’s at least 40 °C/104 °F), the patient might get burned.

steps.title: Apply and mold the splinting material to the injury.
steps.content: Apply and mold the splinting material to the injury. Start by shaping the splint around the joints of the injury. [29] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source Continue to mold the plaster around the injury while the plaster is still a sloppy consistency. Give the patient a head’s up before you start molding the splint, since the process can be a bit painful.

steps.title: Cover the wet splint with Webril and an elastic bandage so it holds its shape.
steps.content: Cover the wet splint with Webril and an elastic bandage so it holds its shape. Grab a section of Webril padding and carefully wrap it around the wet plaster. Then, loop an elastic bandage on top—this helps the splint stay put. If you don’t put a layer of padding down first, the bandage might meld with the plaster as it sets. This will make it really difficult to remove later on.

steps.title: Fold back the edges of the stockinette and padding.
steps.content: Fold back the edges of the stockinette and padding. Maneuver the layers so they bend over the edges of the splint. [30] X Research source This helps it look and feel smooth all around.

steps.title: Keep the injured body part steady and let the splint dry.
steps.content: Keep the injured body part steady and let the splint dry. Remind the patient to keep the injured body part in the right position so the splint sets correctly. Depending on the plaster you used, it may take 2-8 minutes for the splint to set. Plaster labeled as “fast-drying” takes about 5-8 minutes to set, while “extra-fast-drying” plaster only takes 2-4 minutes.
